sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Chitin and chitosan based nanocomposite scaffolds have been widely used for bone
tissue engineering. These chitin and chitosan based scaffolds were reinforced with nanocomponents viz Hydroxyapatite (HAp), Bioglass ceramic (BGC), Silicon dioxide (SiO2), Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) to develop nanocomposite scaffolds. Plenty of works have been reported on the applications and characteristics of the nanoceramic composites however, compiling the work done in this field and presenting it in a single article
3   
is a thrust area. This review is written with an aim to fill this gap and focus on the preparations and applications of chitin or chitosan/nHAp, chitin or chitosan/nBGC, chitin or chitosan/nSiO2, chitin or chitosan/nTiO2 and chitin or chitosan/nZrO2 in the field of bone tissue engineering in detail. Many reports so far exemplify the importance of ceramics in bone regeneration. The effect of nanoceramics over native ceramics in developing composites, its role in osteogenesis etc are the gist of this review.
Keywords: Bioceramics; Chitin; Chitosan; Nanocomposite Scaffolds; Bone Tissue engineering.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, surgical re-establishment using artificial materials as implants to treat
bone defect repair have set up a new baseline in the field of medicine. Nevertheless, the drawbacks associated with these types of treatments have paved way to the evolution of tissue engineering, exploiting the cell-material interactions through the development of three dimensional scaffolds. Polymers, ceramics and metals have been extensively used as materials in the construction of three-dimensional scaffolds for tissue regeneration [1-10]. The 3D scaffolds act as artificial extracellular matrices and provide the necessary cues,
4   
allowing cells to proliferate and maintain their specific functions in the provided niche devoid of any adverse reactions and serve as a template for neo-tissue formation. Owing for a suitable microstructure and mechanical properties, an ideal scaffold for bone regeneration should not only have excellent biocompatibility, biodegradability and non-toxicity, but should also be capable of promoting cell adhesion and retaining the metabolic functions of attached cells [11].
The biocompatible natural polymers chitin and chitosan is currently a subject of
interest in tissue engineering (bone, cartilage, skin etc.) [2, 3, 12,13], drug delivery and wound healing [14]. Chitin consists of 2-acetamido-2-deoxy-β-D-glucose through a β (1 → 4) linkage and is extracted from the shells of marine crustaceans, insects or fungi. Chitin derived from porifera (sponges) has unique biological properties that serve it as a suitable candidate for biomimetic approach [15-18]. Chitosan, a linear polysaccharide, is derived from partial deacetylation of chitin. It is a copolymer of (1→4)-2-acetamido-2-deoxy-β-D-glucan (N-acetyl D-glucosamine) and (1→4)-2-amino-2-deoxy-β-D-glucan (D-glucosamine) units randomly or block distributed, based on the specific method of deacetylation, throughout the biopolymer chain [3]. The structural similarity of chitin and chitosan to glycosaminoglycans, the major component of the extracellular matrix of bone, have made it a suitable scaffold material for tissue engineering [2, 4]. Chemical modification of chitosan is fairly easy due to the presence of the amino group at the C-2 position of the monomer ring, when compared to chitin [19].
Chitin is white, hard, inelastic, nitrogeneous polysaccharide, hydrophobic and is
insoluble in water and most organic solvents unlike hexafluroisopropanol, hexafluroacetone and chloroalcohols [13, 19]. Whereas, chitosan, is soluble in dilute organic acids like acetic acid and formic acid. Preparative procedure of chitin and chitosan are shown in Fig. 1 (a) Chitin and chitosan are excellent functional materials for biomedical applications because of
5   
their high biocompatibility, biodegradability, antibacterial activity, non-antigenicity and high adsorption properties that makes them appropriate for tissue engineering (Fig. 1 (b))[20-24].
Fig. 1
The main advantage of chitin and chitosan is the ease with which they can be
processed into different forms like beads, gels, microparticles, nanoparticles, nanofibers, scaffolds etc. (Fig. 2). Other advantages of chitin and chitosan scaffolds for tissue engineering include the formation of highly porous scaffolds with interconnected pores and to impart osteoconductivity and ability to enhance bone formation both in vitro and in vivo. Enhanced biomineralization in chitin scaffolds have made it a universal template for the regeneration of mineralized tissues [25].
Fig. 2
Chitin and chitosan are good antibacterial and great biocompatible materials that
outweighs their limitation of maintaining mechanical integrity making them suitable for tissue engineering [5, 12,13] and wound healing [13, 14]. Chitin dressings can accelerate wound repair, and regulate secretion of inflammatory mediators such as IL-8, prostaglandin E, IL-1 β, and others [13]. Extensively applied approaches to overcome the constraint of low mechanical property and fast degradation especially in acidic condition or in the presence of lysozyme, are to blend or incorporate other components with chitin/chitosan. The incorporation of nanomaterials basically improves the mechanical strength and biological properties of chitin and chitosan scaffold [7, 26-35].

sections.heading: 2. Applications of chitin or chitosan/nano ceramic composite scaffolds in bone tissue
sections.text:
engineering In the recent years, significant progresses have been achieved to treat the loss or failure of bone defect healing with cell/scaffold based tissue-engineering strategies. Bone replacement or bone defects are treated with autografts, which still remains the gold standard, and
6   
allografts. However, the issues of lack of donor site and associated risk of transmissible disease insist in the development of better techniques. While preparing artificial bone, the following criteria must be considered viz, morphology, structure, inter-connective porosity, sufficient mechanical strength, biocompatibility and biodegradability. From a clinical viewpoint, the use of artificial scaffolds may be attractive to minimize patient discomfort, avoid transmissible infection, wound formation and reduce the cost of treatment.
Natural bone exhibits a hierarchical structure, consisting of fibrilar collagen, which
forms the organic component and HAp, the inorganic component [Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2] (Fig.3).
Biodegradable polymers and bioactive ceramics are blended to mimic the native
polymer-ceramic composite nature of the extracellular matrix for bone tissue engineering scaffolds [35].
Fig. 3
Ceramic materials has found uses increasingly in various fields, viz electronics,
medicine, optical etc. High toughness, temperature withstanding capacity, mouldability etc are their key features. Nano features shows enhanced properties compared to the bulk material. Nanoceramics can be easily synthesized by different methods. In the field of tissue engineering ceramic nanoparticles are increasingly being used in developing bone tissue engineering scaffolds due to its high similarity to inorganic component of bone. This review is divided into different sections that detail the development, in vitro and in vivo responses of nanoceramic composites of chitin and chitosan. The advantages, drawbacks and applications of chitin or chitosan with bioactive ceramic nanomaterials such as HAp, BGC, SiO2, TiO2, ZrO2 for bone tissue engineering applications are being covered here. This review will also highlight directions for future studies to supplement the application of these scaffold systems in translational studies. 2.1. Chitin or Chitosan/ nHAp
7   
Owing to its coherent nature with that of natural bone composition, biocompatibility
and osteoconductivity, nanohydroxyapatite (nHAp) is a widely used biomaterial in bone defect treatment. The properties and applications of nHAp are given in Fig.4 (b). Wei et al. suggested that nHAp particles possess great advantage over micro size HAp, due to their easy dispersion in the polymeric matrix which forms regular pores compared to irregular pores [26].
Fig. 4
HAp alone may not be very efficient for the treatment of all kinds of bone defects due
to its brittleness. There is need for the addition of polymers to improve its properties. Different kinds of synthetic and natural polymers have been blended with nHAp and used for tissue engineering and drug delivery applications [3, 26, 35-89,105-134,137-143]. To effectively mimic the mineral component and the microstructure of natural bone, polymer/nHAp composite scaffolds are being studied as a replacement of human bone. nHAp in the composite materials containing a polymeric matrix not only improves the biochemical properties but also influences the osteoconductiveness, cell proliferation and differentiation [36, 43, 44, 45, 47, 49, 49-54, 57-59,79, 80, 87, 89, 93]. nHAp is synthesized in different forms such as micro particles [103,129], nanoparticles [87-89], nanowires [90] and nanorings [91] and sizes [92], depending on which, properties also vary. Taking advantage of the similarity between chitin and chitosan to native extracellular matrix polymer and the advantages of nHAp as the mineral component of bone, significant research has been conducted on chitin and chitosan nHAP composites for tissue engineering [12]. A few are being discussed here.
nHAp incorporation into chitin or chitosan scaffolds were employed using various
methods based on the interaction between the polymer matrix and ceramics. The most common and effective method of preparation is by the in situ formation of nHAp when the
8   
precursor solutions are homogeneously mixed with chitosan solution, leading to the coprecipitation of nHAp and chitosan [87, 91, 93 -95, 98, 99, 103, 104,107-109]. The preparative method has been described in Fig. 4 (a). Nanocomposite synthesized by this route had a uniform distribution of nHAp that showed exogenous mineralization when incubated in SBF [91, 94, 98, 99]. Chitosan membrane also showed deposition of nHAp when cycles of subsequent immersion in precursor solutions were carried out [110]. Thermally induced phase separation occurs during the development of such nanocomposite scaffolds which are obtained by freeze drying [52]. The incorporation of nHAp in the chitosan matrix by in situ nucleation in the presence of its precursor would provide distinct nano phase distribution of HAp particles and also improve the mechanical strength of the composite compared to simple mixing of nHAp in chitosan. In the case of fibrous scaffolds, addition of binders or synthetic polymers helps in the easy incorporation of nHAp into the organic solution [94, 101, 111]. Nanocomposites prepared by dispersing nHAp in chitin solution with and without crosslinking have also been developed [51,105,106]. Chitin/nHAp hybrid gels resulted in ten time’s higher mechanical strength than control chitin gel as well as good biocompatibility [51]. Chitin-poly(caprolactone) injectable hydrogel with nHAp developed showed enhanced osteogenic differentiation of rASCs which was confirmed by ALP quantification and by immunocytochemistry, which shows the expression of osteo-specific proteins [80]. Murugan et al. reported the development of bone paste by mixing the soft nano precipitate of HAp obtained from the wet chemical synthesis using Ca and P precursors and chitosan solution, allowed for interaction and vacuum dried to yield nHAp/chitosan paste [69]. A similar approach was done to develop a guided bone regeneration membrane by homogeneously mixing chitosan and nHAp slurry [79]. Homogenous, transparent and high strength CS/nHAp nanocomposite which contains a chitosan matrix obtained by precipitation and filler of HAp synthesized simultaneously by in situ hybridization have been reported. The presence of
9   
amino group in chitosan enables its protonation and deprotonation depending on the solution pH. In this method chitosan tends to precipitate along with HAp formation that takes place at pH of 10. The slow neutralization process employing the infiltration of base through a chitosan membrane allowed a layer by layer arrangement of CS/nHAp layers, compared to conventional techniques of mixing precursor and neutralizing which yields irregular arrangement [45].
CS/nHAp composite bone cement containing strength reinforcing agent, calcium
carbonate (CaCO3), and setting accelerator, calcium oxide (CaO), improved the setting time and strength and the developed composite showed surface wettability enhancing the cell material interaction [97]. The addition of setting accelerators and strength reinforcing agents improve the mechanical strength of the composite. The progressive polymerization of composite was observed which yields in a doubled up mechanical strength which is favorable for the treatment of osseous defects. Other additives like citric acid acts as an inhibitor of HAp crystallization leading to the formation of brushite and calcium phosphates. An enlargement of the precipitates was also observed, solely due to the electrostatic interaction of citric acid with chitosan [99]. Sodium silicate on the other hand acts as a nucleation agent. Chitosan membrane immersed in sodium silicate showed nucleation of HAp on the surface of membrane. The size ranged from 1-5microns depending on the SBF exposure time. Distinct phase of calcium sulfate was observed in the HAp formed. C6 in chitosan has a free hydroxyl group that can help activation of the membrane surface by silanol groups of the sodium silicate solution. The silicate ions in the SS solution are adsorbed on the chitosan substrate followed by HAp nucleation of the adsorbed silicate ions. HAp nucleons grow because of the saturated 1.5 SBF solution, leading to the coating of the substrate [112]. When a scaffold is implanted, it interacts with body fluid and forms an initial calcium complex and later on initiates the nucleation of apatite, in the presence of phosphate ions in the surrounding fluid.
10   
This phenomenon was employed by Manjubala et al. in developing nHAp depositions in chitosan sponge by the double diffusion method [98].
Nanocomposites have also been prepared by cross-linking chemistry, wherein the
chitosan is made to interact with functionalized HAp. Deepan et al. initially grafted polypropylene groups on to chitosan in acidic conditions by hydroxypropylation followed by reaction with ethylene glycol functionalized nHAp [40]. Covalent linkage between the hydroxypropyl groups of chitosan and f-nHAp forms a network structure. Thus nHAp forms an integral part of the chitosan structure rather than reinforcements. This is anticipated to impart high modulus and strength. Freeze drying provides an interconnected pore structure for cell infiltration. Li et al. utilized casting/solvent evaporation to develop genipin crosslinked chitosan/nHAp composite [113]. FTIR results confirm the shift in amine band of chitosan possibly due to its interaction with genipin. This method helps in increasing the binding between chitosan in the polymer matrix thereby entrapping more nHAp. Electrostatic interaction between the amine groups of chitosan and phosphate group of nHAp was also observed. Recently, urease-catalyzed decomposition of urea was used to regulate pH in the synthesis reaction, to successfully precipitate HAp based composites. The nanocomposite prepared by this method showed nHAp crystals of shape, size and crystallinity index similar to natural bone. Precipitation of n-HA/CS was obtained by stirring a mixed aqueous solution containing Ca(NO3)2, Na2HPO4, urea, urease and chitosan at 37°C. Nanocomposite prepared by this method also showed enhanced mechanical properties. The size of nHAp crystals was 25-40nm which falls in the range of natural bone inorganic mineral size. Further, this method is promising in developing non-sintering and drug-loaded bioceramics with improved biomechanical features [114].
In general, most studies report enhanced cell viability, attachment, growth and
differentiation of osteoblastic cells on chitosan/nHAp composites as compared to plain
11   
chitosan constructs [93, 97, 98]. Cytocompatibility test of chitosan (Mw 250kDa, DDA of 80%) nHAp nanocomposite developed using Ca salts as additives was done using human MG63 cells which revealed significant increase in proliferation over a period of 7 and11 days in culture as compared to control chitosan [97]. This study as well as others attributes to the improved viability and growth due to the addition of nHAp. In vitro osteogenic differentiation study on nHAp/chitosan (Mw 469 kDa and DDA 92.3%) developed by in situ co-precipitation method, showed a significantly improved bone specific protein, osteocalcin (OCN) expression, which is indicative of the maturation and mineralization phase of the osteogenic differentiation phases [79, 80, 89, 94, 107, 115, 120,122,123]. It is also suggested that nHAp could enhance the coating of apatite layer on biomaterials, which could be used to produce apatite polymer composite scaffolds [93]. The rate of bioresorption of nHAp was improved by the addition of chitosan. The viscoelastic nature of composites would prevent the migration of particulate into the surrounding tissue upon post-implantation. Besides, smoothness of the composites may not damage or harm any soft tissues around the implant [69]. A homogeneous mineralization could be achieved by double diffusion method wherein nHAp deposits along the pores of the chitosan sponge which shows early mineralization and ALP activity than unmineralized scaffold [98]. The antibacterial property of nHAp has also been reported. The possible explanation for this phenomenon would be its small size which could disrupt the cell membrane and cytoplasm of bacteria [109].
Ma et al. studied the in vivo effects of sponge-like chitosan/nHAp prepared by cross-
linking with gluteraldehyde (DDA of chitosan is 91.2%) with standard critical-sized calvarial bone defect (~ 6.5 mm) which was created in Sprague-Dawley rats. The rats were separated into two groups, chitosan/nHAp implanted (group 1) and control defect group wherein no scaffolds was implanted (group 2). After 1 week, the histological assessment of group 1 clearly showed that a large number of living cells were anchored in the pores of the
12   
chitosan/nHAp implants. New bone formation, both at the edge and in the center of implants, was found in as early as 2 weeks. Histological assays confirmed that the freshly formed bone tissue was bioactive and neovascularized. After 5 weeks, the mineral content and volume of the newly formed bone tissue in the defects were significantly greater in group 1 than in group 2 (p < 0.01). This study confirms the importance of the developed chitosan/nHAp scaffold for craniofacial defect treatment although the effect of nHAp in bone regeneration was not explored [64]. Subcutaneous implantation of chitosan/PLGA/nHAp showed ectopic osteoid formation only in the presence of predifferentiated umbilical cord MSCs [111]. Another study on chitosan/silk/nHAp fibrous membrane also showed higher de novo bone formation in hMSCs laden construct [124]. The osteoconductive effect of nHAp significantly rely its size, structure and composition. The higher concentration of nHAp in scaffold imparts greater surface energy and stimulates mineralization and enhanced bone formation. For ectopic bone formation either mechanical stimulation from scaffolds or from host is necessary. Further, osteoinductivity of the scaffold will show enhanced migration and differentiation of cells at the site. BMSCs seeded chitosan/nHAP scaffold showed better ectopic bone formation when implanted intramuscularly [125]. Integrin-BMP/Smad signaling pathway activation was the reason for osteogenic differentiation of cells cultured in the nanocomposite [94]. Orthotopic application of Zn doped chitosan/β-GP/nHAp showed significant healing in critical sized rat bone defect within 2 weeks which shows the effect of nHAp in bone regeneration [126]. Similar bioactivity was observed in nHAp/chitosanphosphorylated chitosan polyelectrolyte complex implanted in rabbit femur marrow cavity [58].
The incorporation of nHAp have shown remarkable effects when it comes to
improving mechanical property of the composite [114], enhancing osteogenesis in vitro [93, 97, 98] and in vivo [64, 125]. Incorporation of metals into HAp in the form of coating or
13   
dopants has further enhanced the properties of HAp. Saravanan et al. developed a biocomposite scaffold containing chitosan, nHAp and nano-silver particles (CS/nHAp/nAg) by freeze drying technique, followed by introduction of silver nanoparticles through reduction phenomenon by functional groups of chitosan. Lone pair electrons present in the nitrogen and oxygen atoms of the functional groups of chitosan reduce the silver ion to metal silver nanoparticles. This leads to the formation of surface adsorbed nAg which showed efficient antibacterial activity. An indirect cytotoxicity assay studied for the nanocomposite showed no toxicity on rat primary calvarial osteoprogenitor cells and human osteosarcoma cells [74].
Tripathi et al. developed bio-composite scaffolds containing chitosan (CS), nHAp and
Cu-Zn alloy nanoparticles (nCu-Zn) by freeze drying technique. The scaffolds revealed a macroporous architecture suggested for cell penetration, bone tissue in growth. The nCu-Zn particles were distributed onto the CS-nHAp matrix. The incorporation of nanoparticles increased swelling, decreased degradation, and increased protein adsorption properties compared to control scaffolds. The antibacterial activity against S. aureus and E. coli and osteoproliferative property studied on osteoprogenitor cells isolated from Wistar rat of the scaffolds were due to the presence of Cu-Zn nanoparticles [78]. In view of incorporating antibacterial properties containing metal zinc was doped onto nHAp [127]. A macroporous scaffold was developed by blending chitosan (Mw 230 kDa, DDA 86%), PEG and nHApZnO. The formed scaffold showed a linear dependency of water uptake and PEG concentration. Antibacterial effect was proved using Escherichia coli, Lysinibacillus fusiformis and Bacillus cereus. 15 wt % nHAp-ZnO showed the maximum zone of inhibition showing a concentration dependent pattern. The scaffold was non-hemolytic and non toxic. Osteoblast-like MG-63 cells grew, attached and proliferated on these nanocomposites without having any negative effect and showed good cytocompatibility [128]. Biomaterials containing nHAp-Cu/PEG 400 can be used as antibacterial materials as the Cu coating on
14   
nHAp showed antibacterial activity against gram positive bacterial strains [129]. Such coatings on bone implants would provide protection against common infection that is a major issue pertaining to bone implants that finally lead to loss of regeneration, implant loosening and chronic infections. Sr doped HAp nanorods were synthesized by hydrothermal method. A hydrophilic drug Prami and a hydrophobic drug Risp were encapsulated in SrHAp nanorods and the obtained drug-nanorod system was coated with the biocompatible polymeric matrix CS-g-PHEMA. The mesoporous structure enhanced the release of hydrophilic drug in a fast manner, whereas the release of hydrophobic drug was significantly improved by the dissolution of SrHAp. No significant toxicity was observed by the kinetics of the cell proliferation potential and the assessment of the cell viability in Caco-2 cell cultures when the SRHAp was coated with CS-g-PHEMA [130].
The easy and reproducible synthesis routes of nHAp have made it a widely utilized
bioceramics in the tissue engineering field. It could also be utilized for the delivery of biomolecules to the site [131-134], chemically modified to act as diagnostic agents [135, 136] etc. Although chitosan-nHAp composite biomaterials have proven their worth as potential scaffold systems, ternary composite systems have also been widely prepared employing chitosan/nHAp with β-glycerophosphate [48-49], polyamide-6,6 [46], Poly(vinyl alcohol)[67], poly (caprolactone) [80], hyaluronic acid [88], poly(galacturonic acid) [98], chondroitin sulphate [108], amylopectin [108], poly(lactide-co-glycolide) [111], cellulose [115], collagen [53, 118], starch [117], gelatin [120,141,143], carboxymethyl cellulose [55, 61, 62, 65, 115, 122], magnetite [36], poly(L-lactic acid) [140] and konjac glucomannan [142] for bone tissue engineering. 2. 2. Chitin or Chitosan/ nBGC Bioactive glass ceramics are silicate-based materials used in orthopedics and dentistry [111, 144, 125]. They can interact with hard tissue and are superior to HAp in their ability for neo
15   
bone development, osteoblast proliferation and stromal cell differentiation [111, 144-151]. In addition, it enhances the differentiation marker expression like ALP, OCN and OPN [150, 151]. Bioactive glass ceramic nanoparticles (nBGC) are mostly prepared by sol-gel technique[148]. Mesoporous bioglass particles were developed by incorporating surfactants during sol-gel process. The resultant nBGC possesses uniform and adequate mesoporosity, controllable nanopore size and pore volume, excellent cytocompatibility and apatite mineralization [151].
Incorporation of nBGC into chitosan involves simple homogenization by blending or
sonication [111,145]. Unlike HAp in situ preparation of nBGC in the composite is not reported. Homogenized nBGC into a part of solvent mixture of 7:3 formic acid:acetone was later mixed with chitosan and PCL solution for the development of fibrous nBGC loaded chitosan/PCL fibers [111]. High molecular weight PEO was homogenized with nBGC to form a clear solution which was further mixed with low molecular weight chitosan with degree of deacetylation, DD ≥ 75% solution to yield fibers. nBGC being ceramic, has an insulating property which hinders electrospinning at higher concentrations. An increase in fiber diameter with the increase in nBGC was also observed even though Shalumon et al. and Talebian et al. had successfully incorporated 3 wt% nBGC into the fibers [111,145]. Similiarly chitin/nBGC nanocomposite scaffold was prepared by homogenizing α-chitin hydrogel and 1% nBGC followed by lyophilization to yield a macroporous scaffold with controlled swelling [153]. β-chitin/nBGC nanocomposite formed a macroporous scaffold with pore size comparatively lower than control β-chitin scaffold. The preparation procedure of chitin/nBGC composite is given in Fig. 5 (a) and, properties and applications of nBGC are given in Fig. 5 (b). Slow degradation rate of the nanocomposite was observed which may be due to the neutralizing effect on lysozyme due to the leachable products of bioglass which provides an alkaline environment [154]. Chitosan (Mw-100-150kDa and DD=85%) was used
16   
to form nanocomposite scaffold containing 1% nBGC using gluteraldehyde as cross-linker. A low density, macroporous scaffold was formed after lyophilization technique which showed a declined degradation rate (5% weight loss for nanocomposite and 25% weight loss for chitosan control) [155]. Addition of gelatin to the chitosan nBGC composite showed no significant improvement [156]. Pourhaghgouy et al. developed freeze-cast chitosan nanocomposite scaffolds reinforced with bioactive glass. Freeze casting was done by pouring the homogeneous solution of chitosan and 10 to 50 weight % of nBGC (% weight of chitosan powder) into a PTFE mould immersed in liquid nitrogen with controlled cooling after which lyophilization was carried out. A unidirectional pore structure was formed with uniform distribution of nBGCs. The compressive strength and compressive moduli values increased 4 fold and 10 fold respectively with the addition of 50% nBGCs. The authors reported an optimum concentration of 30% suitable for bioactivity [157]. Ravarian et al. prepared chitosan/nBGC nanocomposite scaffold using γ-glycidoxy propyl trimethoxy silane functionalized chitosan which was chemically bonded with bioglass during sol-gel method. In sol-gel method the bioglass (20-100 vol %) and polymer solutions were mixed for a period of 1 h at room temperature to form a homogenous solution of pH 2-3. Further the mixture was aged for the formation of Si-O-Si covalent bonds between functionalized chitosan and bioglass and fabrication of gel structure. By titling method the formation of gel was confirmed following which it was dried subsequently in room temperature and 37°C. To develop a porous chitosan/nBGC hybrid scaffold sodium bicarbonate was used as a foaming agent. The study showed that a concentration of <40 vol% nBGC formed a homogeneous structure with controlled gelation time (<30min). A significant reduction in swelling ratio and enzymatic degradation was observed with the increase of nBGC concentration which is attributed to the strong covalent bond between chitosan and bioglass. When compared to physically mixed scaffold the hybrid scaffolds were less brittle owing to the nanophase
17   
interaction between chitosan and bioglass, though there was a 7 fold reduction in young’s moduli. The scaffolds developed by this method would be suitable for non-load bearing implant applications [158]. A Chitosan-45S5 BG-PHBV microsphere (CS-nBG-MS) membrane was prepared through solution casting method using low viscosity chitosan. The developed PHBV microspheres were loaded with drugs daidzein (anti-osteoporotic) and tetracycline hydrochloride (antibacterial) and it showed a controlled release owing due to the chitosan/nBGC matrix which acts as a barrier [159]. The developed bioactive membranes with potential multi-drug delivery capability would be promising candidate membranes for GTR/GBR applications.
Fig. 5
nBGCs incorporated nanocomposite scaffolds showed a nBGC concentration
dependant toxicity towards cells [144]. The ions that leach out from the bioglass would be responsible to the hyperosmotic shock which is a concentration dependant mechanism. An optimum concentration of nBGC showed an enhanced mitogenic activity and cell maturation. The osteostimulating effect of nBGCs has also been widely explored. The ions produced osteostimulation when present at a particular concentration range of 15-30 ppm Si and 60-90 ppm Ca. The underlying mechanism involves the intracellular uptake of the bioactive Ca2+ and Si4+ ions that releases from the dissolution of nBGC, which showed an early activation of factors responsible for cell proliferation and differentiation; including transcription factors(cjun, fra-1, c-myc and AP-1) and cell cycle regulators (cyclin D1), apoptosis regulators, DNA synthesis and repair, growth factors (VEGF, IGF-II), signal transduction molecules, ECM components etc. The production of extracellular proteins is enhanced in the presence of the ionic dissolution products of bioactive glass [144]. The mechanically strong apatite layer formation between the bioglass layer and the native bone is indicative of the osteostimulation of bioglass. It was reported that the dissolution of Ca ions impart super saturation of the
18   
surrounding body fluid and the leached Si ions act as the nucleation sites for the formation of apatite layer [147]. This thus creates a strong interaction between the bioglass entity with the native bone. Turdean et al studied the in vitro short-time stability of chitosan and chitosan/nBGC coatings by cyclic voltammetry [170]. The formation of a new outer biomimetic and biologically active hydroxyapatite protective layer occurred over the nanocomposite implicating the use of such nanocomposite coatings for in vivo devices. Bosetti et al. compared different bioactive glasses for its osteoconductiveness from which 45S and 77S provided a favourable situation for marrow cells to differentiate to osteoblast like cells and mineralised nodule formation. 77S bioactive glass further inhibitted osteoclastlike cells formation. Bioglass dissolutes have also shown to influence stem cell differentiation versus osteoclasts differentiation [148]. Leu et al. expanding upon prior work of Day et al. showed the upregulation of VEGF production in human micro-vascular endothelial cells, projecting the stimulation of angiogenesis by the dissolution products of bioglass [161,162]. Thus the incorporation of bioactive glasses in nanoforms into tissue engineering constructs would be promising in the aspect of bone regeneration. nBGC based chitin scaffolds have been used in alveolar/periodontal bone tissue engineering applications [111,148,149].
The SEM images of β-chitin/nBGC mineralized nodules in 7, 14 and 21 days
respectively indicate enhanced matrix deposition and mineralization in the absence of osteogenic supplements [153,154]. 30% enhancement of cell viability on the surface of nanocomposite compared to pure bioglass was observed which was again increased by 20% in the chitosan/nBGC hybrid scaffold [157]. In vitro bioactivity was confirmed by the apatite layer formation after soaking in SBF for various time points. Five stages occur during the mineralization process. Firstly the Ca or sodium (Na) ions in the bioglass are released into the SBF solution. Further, the soluble silica is lost in the form of Si(OH)4 into the solution as a result of the breakage of Si-O-Si bonds to form silanol groups (Si-OH) which induce apatite
19   
nucleation (stages II and III). Once apatite nuclei are formed, they can grow yielding a uniform layer by consuming the Ca and P ions from SBF (stages IV and V) [163]. For chitosan/nBGC 30% needle shaped protrusion arranged in cauliflower pattern was observed after 5 days of incubation in SBF which was confirmed to be hydroxyapatite using EDS analysis, which was absent in the control chitosan scaffold [184]. The metabolic activity of hPDL and hBMSC was enhanced on the addition of nBGCs to the chitosan membranes. Further an increase in hPDL cell proliferation on the nanocomposite with greater cell matrix mineralization was also observed [164]. Mineralized nodule formation is basically considered to be the final result of differentiation and function of the osteoblasts. Nano-sized bioactive particles provide advantages over conventional (micron-sized) bioactive glasses, which result from the large surface area of the nBGC; nanocomposite membranes had enhanced performance in terms of mechanical properties bioactivity [163]. Chitosan/nBGC (Chitosan Mw = 190 -310 kDa, DDA = 75-85% and viscosity 200-800 cps and nBGC concentration of 0.9 wt%) composite scaffolds fabricated via freeze drying method were studied for possible application as shape-memory bone implantable materials for tissue regeneration. The hydration of the scaffold after implanting in pig femur defect showed a complete packing in the defect [165].
The reinforcing effect of nBGC as the nanofillers is an added advantage to the
mineralization capability, thereby, making a promising bone tissue engineering construct. Bioactive membranes with multi-drug delivery capability showed low toxicity towards MG63 cells. The nBGC addition promoted MG-63 cell adhesion and maturation, indicated by the extensive proliferation and ALP activity [159]. The use of mesoporous bioglass (MBG) for the development of a nanocomposite with chitosan as a carrier for DNA was carried out by Luo et al. The developed composite nanoparticle showed size of 200nm and showed enhanced gene transfection efficiency on the two cell lines tested, Hela cells and MG-63. The
20   
tendency of MBG to release higher amount of Ca ions forms complexes with the pOGP (osteogenic growth peptide) leading to its protection against nucleases and higher transfection efficiency. In short, the amphiphilic chitosan-PCL-mPEG provides the foundation of transfection efficiency, and the MBG as an enhancer [166]. Under the light of the differentiation studies carried out and the quantification of ALP activity and mineralization the nBGC containing scaffolds showed high ALP activity by 14 days compared to control. Higher calcium deposition was also observed in the nanocomposites which is an indicator of the mineralization phase of osteogenic differentiation. The mesoporous chitosan-bioglass hybrids owing to the strong covalent bonding demonstrated to have positive effects on the attachment and viability of primary human osteoblasts [158].
In effect, the presence of nano-scale interactions in addition to the bioactive nature of
bioglass materials the osteogenic potential of chitin/chitosan scaffolds are highly pronounced thereby leading to strong apatite layer formation (mineralization), improved mechanical strength, in vitro osteoblast maturation etc. It would not be an exaggeration that under this scenario, the developed nano-composite scaffolds are a potential candidate for bone regeneration [144-158]. It has been reported that chitosan/bioglass developed by freeze drying method has shown de novo bone regeneration, enhanced osseointegration and ECM synthesis in an in vivo study conducted in ovariectomised rat model [167], but so far in vivo data support is still lacking in field.
Considering the advantages of mesoporous bioglass ceramic particles (MBGC)
various works have been reported that deals with the modification of MBGCs. Doping MBGCs with bioactive metals have proved beneficial in terms of improving the osteoconductiveness of the ceramics without hindering the physical properties of bioglass. The incorporation of Boron in bioglass was done by Gorustovich et al. and analyzed the activity in vivo in rat tibia defect [168]. Boron is a metal that exhibit potential applications in
21   
bone regeneration. Being a trace element required in diet, boron has significant roles in embryogenesis, bone growth, and immune and psychomotor functions [169]. Further, Nielsen et al. showed that diet deficient in B detrimentally affected bone strength, shape and mineral element composition in rats [170]. The neoformed bone tissue around boron-modified bioactive glass particles system implanted in rat tibia bone marrow by histologic, histomorphometric and microchemical evaluation showed an early bone formation suggesting the stimulation of osteoprogenitor cells to form mature osteoblasts thus acting as a suitable niche for bone regeneration [168]. Incorporation of dexamethasone into boron modified bioactive glass showed a sustained release due to the mesoporous structure of the scaffold. Significant enhancement in the proliferation and the expression of Col I and Rux2 of osteoblasts was achieved which is supported by the released B and dexamethasone [171].
Another metal dopant is Strontium (Sr). The pH dependant change in proliferation of
osteoblasts on strontium doped borosilicate scaffold suggested that the alkaline pH supported the dissolution of boron, enhancing osteoblasts proliferation, apatite formation and neobone development in vivo in rat tibia defect model [173]. Bioactive glasses (BG) which contain strontium have the potential to combine the known bone regenerative properties of BG with the anabolic and anti-catabolic effects of strontium cations. A BG series (SiO2-P2O5-Na2OCaO) in which 0-100% of the calcium was substituted by strontium was prepared. The Sr released from the strontium-substituted BG enhanced the metabolic activity in osteoblasts with an inhibition of osteoclast activity by reducing tartarate resistant acid phosphatase activity and inhibiting resorption of calcium phosphate films in a dose-dependent manner. Osteoblasts proliferation and alkaline phosphatase activity showed a direct relationship with strontium substitution; on the other hand, osteoclasts adopted typical resorption morphology. The studies conducted by Gentleman et al. showed that strontium substitution of BG promote
22   
an anabolic effect on osteoblasts and an anti-catabolic effect on osteoclasts making it suitable for bone regeneration [173].
The importance of bioglass, its various compositions, scaffolds etc are well explored
but the nanocomposites developed with bioglass have been studied only in vitro [144- 166,168-173]. Though promising results have been observed in in vitro studies, the cycle is still incomplete without strong proofs from in vivo studies. 2.3. Chitin or Chitosan/ nSiO2
SiO2 is a component of bioactive glasses and is found to have apatite forming ability
in SBF [174]. nSiO2 or silica meets many of the requirements associated with an ideal material for grafting and scaffolding (Fig.6b). Silica can be easily prepared by Stober method [175], hydrolysis [176, 177], spray drying [178], sol-gel [178, 179], semi burned rice straw [180] etc. with numerous topological forms e.g., nanoparticles [176,178,179,181], nanotubes [182, 183], nanospheres [184], ultrathin films [185], and mesoporous silica [178,186,187,188] holding great potential applications in the field of photonics/optics, drugdelivery, microelectronics, tissue engineering and catalysis [175-191]. Silica gel coating have also shown to produce an insulating layer over metal nanoparticles [192]. In scaffold fabrication techniques the large specific surface area of nSiO2 can form a tighter interface with the polymer matrix in composites yielding a mechanically strong nanocomposite. The properties and applications of nSiO2 are shown in Fig. 6b. Scaffolds derived from sponges and diatoms are the source of chitin biocomposites having enhanced mineralization properties. This has become the source for developing naturally inspired silica-chitin scaffolds [193-195]. Introduction of nSiO2 particles can not only endow polymeric scaffolds with biomineralization capability but also increase the stiffness of polymer material without greatly decreasing the mechanical strength. Silanol group present on the surface is a preferable region for modifications with different osteoinductive agents, such as certain
23   
peptides, proteins or growth factors [188, 196, 197]. Silica derivatives have been introduced as bone substitutes and were reported with good clinical success rates and promotion of new vital bone surrounding these materials and also as bio-mimetic agents to coat implant surfaces to provide the suitable substrate for osteoblasts culture.
Fig. 6
The incorporation of nSiO2 into chitin/ chitosan matrix adds osteogenic activity to the
composite. The preparation of nanocomposite generally involves the homogenization of matrix polymer with pre synthesized nSiO2 powders [Fig. 6a]. Addition of nSiO2 (10nm,99%) to chitin to form a 1% chitin/nSiO2 nanocomposite which showed enhanced biomineralization when immersed in SBF for 7 and 14 days [28]. Similar observation were seen when nSiO2 (10nm, 99%) was incorporated in chitosan/chondroitin sulfate and chitosan/gelatin matrix (chitosan Mw 50-190 kDa, DDA 75-85%)) [198,199]. The composite scaffolds were fabricated by freeze-drying and lyophilization method. The prepared nanocomposite scaffolds showed excellent porosity, degradation, biomineralization, mechanical integrity and protein adsorption. The addition of nSiO2 improved the binding of the parent polymers acting as reinforcement as observed when it was incorporated into PCL solution [200, 201] and chitosan/PEO solution for electrospinning [202].Chitosan (low molecular weight, 75-85% DDA) in combination with nSiO2 (10-20nm) and zirconia (<100nm) also formed porous, slow degrading, swelling scaffold developed by freeze drying method [203]. Compressive strength up to 42 MPa was achieved by the formation of an interpenetrating network structure between poly(acrylic acid) and chitosan (DDA 85%; viscosity: 5 CPS, 20°C; Mw 50-60 kDa) with nSiO2 (colloidal, 20-30 nm) as the filler [204].
To produce uniform coating of nSiO2 by electrophoretic deposition chitosan was
employed for stabilizing the electrosteric and charging of ceramic nanoparticles. Relatively thick coatings in the range of up to 100 μm could be developed. The induced osteogenic
24   
activity in vitro and in vivo in rabbit calvarial defect model was directly proportional to the nSiO2 content in the coating [205, 206]. The mineralization ability of nanocomposites was significantly improved due to the presence of silanol groups (Si-OH) which play a major role in the apatite formation. They act as chelating agents on Ca and PO4 ions present in SBF and act as nucleating sites for HAp deposition [28,198]. A pH-responsive chitosan-functionalized mesoporous nSiO2 was fabricated for dual-delivery of BMP-2 and dexamethasone. The mesoporous nSiO2 were prepared by a CTAB-templated sol-gel method, and further coated by chitosan via the cross-linking of glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (GPTMS). The mesopores hosted the small dexamethasone molecules whereas BMP-2 was functionalized into the chitosan coating. The developed carrier showed enhanced co-loading BMP-2 and dexamethasone, without losing its bioactivity and showed efficient intracellular and ensuing pH-responsive controlled release of dexamethasone in cytosol [207].
Cytocompatibility studies confirmed the nontoxic behavior of the developed
nanocomposites. The toxicity of nSiO2 could be highly reduced by blending it into composites [200, 201]. The scaffolds were found to be bioactive and biocompatible with MG63, hMSCs, bMSCs etc [198-201, 207]. These results suggest that chitin/nSiO2 composite scaffolds can be useful for bone tissue engineering[27]. The co delivery of BMP-2 and dexamethasone enhanced the osteogenic differentiation of bMSCs confirmed by ALP activity and cell mineralization. The gene expression of osteogenic transcription factors and osteoblast markers were also measured with real-time RT-PCR assay, which showed significant expression of RUNX2, ALP, OCN, OPN and collagen I in both time points analyzed (4 and 7 days). Ectopic bone formation in the thigh muscle pouches of mice was observed when treated with the chitosan/nSiO2 embedded with BMP2 and dexamethasone within 2 weeks. The bone density and volume was significant over control treatment [207]. In addition, in vivo bone healing capacity was enhanced in nSiO2 containing chitosan hybrid
25   
scaffolds with and without the use of biomolecules and blending polymers [204, 207-209]. nSiO2 also showed enhanced apatite formation when incorporated in chitosan alginate scaffold [191].
The use of sol-gel method for preparing nSiO2 offers greater advantage in terms of
encapsulation and drug release efficacy. The release rate can be effectively controlled by tailoring the internal structure of the particles, its pore size, drug-nanoparticle interactions. Moreover sol-gel method successfully generates micro or nanoparticles by the precise control of surfactants compared to spray drying method [178,188]. Highly monodispersed, stable aqueous suspension of nSiO2 were surface-functionalized with amino groups for binding of DNA. The in vitro and in vivo transfection ability was significantly increased by this method [209]. Various others studies report the use of nSiO2 to load DNA [210]. Chitosan which could be easily functionalized was utilized to form capping for mesoporous nSiO2 particles thereby reducing the initial burst of biomolecules encapsulated in the pores of silica [211, 212]. The healing process in vivo was accelerated in the critical calvarial defect model in rat when treated with chitosan/nSiO2 hybrid membrane with localized BMP2 [208]. The observed properties by the incorporation of nSiO2 may be due to the fact that nSiO2 is known to stimulate osteogenic properties in stem cells and osteoblasts. The addition of nSiO2 in chitin and chitosan significantly increases the osteoblast function and renders the material useful for bone tissue engineering. The potential of the hybrids as a drug eluting bone replacement could also be considered. 2.4. Chitin or Chitosan/ nTiO2 Titanium metal oxide (TiO2) layer which is formed on the surface of the Ti implants is solely responsible for the bioactive property of the material, making it the highly recommended implant material for bone defects. The bioactive property of this metal oxide layer has paved way in developing micro and nanoparticles for various applications like photo catalysts, gas
26   
sensors and biomaterials [213, 214] (Fig 7b). In fact, TiO2 nanoparticles have been recently proposed as attractive filler materials for biodegradable polymer matrices to impart strength and bioactivity and have been classified under the category of ceramics [215-218]. The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 in the presence of oxygen and surface adsorbed water result in free radical species generation, which can attack any organic molecule decomposing it into CO2 and H2O. Lipid peroxidation reaction is known to be the underlying mechanism of its bactericidal property which causes peroxidation of the polyunsaturated phospholipid component of the lipid membrane initially and induce major disorder in the cell membrane leading to loss of essential functions that rely on intact cell membrane architecture, such as respiratory activity leading to cell death [219]. The osteogenic property of titania was reported by Kasuga et al. TiO2 in the presence of adsorbed water forms titanium hydroxide. It acts as nucleation sites for bone like apatite crystallization. TiO2 powder compacts after light illuminated and incubated in SBF for 10 days at 37°C, bone like apatite crystals were formed on its surfaces [220, 221]. Chitosan-titania (Chitosan-TiO2) nanocomposites have been prepared via sol-gel process. In this study tetra ethyl ortho titanate (C8H20O4Ti) was used as a precursor to introduce titania network in the chitosan matrix. This route of synthesis of nanocomposite yielded a nanocomposite with improved mechanical properties due to the homogeneous and ordered distribution of titania particles (5-25 nm) in the chitosan matrix resulting from the large interfacial interaction between the basic sites (NH2) available on the polymer chains and Lewis acidic sites from titanium [222]. Haldorai et al. developed chitosan-TiO2 nano hybrids via chemical precipitation method by dissolving chitosan and titania in dilute acetic acid. The formed Ti4+ ions interact with the hydroxyl and amine groups of chitosan, further precipitating the hybrid using NaOH. The nanoparticles of size 100- 300nm had a Ti core with chitosan shell [223]. Macroporous microspheres of chitosan and titania was developed by dipping chitosan beads in titania solution. The Ti-O-Ti condensation
27   
inside the chitosan alcogel induces a sort of coating of chitosan fibers with the TiO2, which decreases the texture shrinkage occurring during drying process [224].
The development of nTiO2 incorporated chitin chitosan scaffold is illustrated in Fig.
7a. Jayakumar et al. 2011 prepared the nano needle shaped TiO2 incorporated chitin-chitosan composite scaffolds using lyophilization technique for bone tissue engineering [29]. The prepared composite scaffold showed controlled degradation when compared to the control scaffold. In addition, the nanocomposite scaffold showed an enhanced bioactivity. Cytocompatibility and cell attachment of the composite scaffold was studied using osteoblast-like cells (MG-63), fibroblast cells (L929) and human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) indicating the cytocompatible nature of the developed nanocomposite [29]. Antimicrobial properties of chitosan/nTiO2 have been proved useful in textile industry as well as bone and skin tissue engineering [225, 226]. Chitosan/nTiO2 nanocomposites were prepared by in situ sol - gel process. Protein adsorption showed an inverse relation with the size of the nanoparticle and similar was the case for apatite formation. Biocompatible nanocomposite scaffolds with antimicrobial activity also showed superior activity in vivo [225]. The highly positive chitosan-TiO2 nanohybrid particles readily enter the Gram negative bacteria and interact with lipid membrane leading to loss of respiration and viability [223]. The presence of free radicals also deteriorates the viability of bacteria [223, 227]. The method of synthesis of chitosan-nTiO2 by precipitation, hydrothermal and in situ sol-gel methods has no significant effect on the bioactivity and antibacterial activity, whereas it influences cytotoxicity. The nanocomposite has an important function in conferring better biocompatibility as it masks the cytotoxic effect of TiO2 [228, 229].
The size of nano component should also be considered in making nanocomposite, as
their dimensions itself shows varied responses in vitro and in vivo. Brammer et al. has pointed out the various types of nanotubes developed and its various dimensions that show
28   
remarkable properties in osteogenesis [230]. Further biomolecule delivery (growth factors or proteins or drug) to the site (local delivery) was also achieved using titania nanotubes [230, 231]. A comparative study on the effect of nano and micro structures of titania in decreasing S. epidermis adhesion and increased osteoblasts functions was reported. The antibacterial effect of titania would be detrimental towards biofilm formation in cases of nosocomial infections in implant area [232]. Thus, nTiO2 based polymer composites owing to its antibacterial activity post photoactivation and osteointegration following appropriate synthesis methods are recommended for implant and tissue engineering applications.

sections.heading: 2.5. Chitin or Chitosan/ nZrO2
sections.text:
Zirconia, a metal oxide of zirconium, has found significant importance as ceramic
biomaterial due to its chemical and dimensional stability, high mechanical strength, toughness, and Young's modulus comparable to that of stainless steel alloys. Zirconia has been shown to be biocompatible as titanium and it has been widely used to build prosthetic devices due to its good mechanical strength and osseointegration [233]. The unique combination of biocompatibility, bioactivity, osteointegration, mechanical toughness and radiopacity make it a highly opted bone implants better than titania [234]. Osteoblasts were able to proliferate and differentiate on zirconia without any adverse reactions [235, 236]. Zirconia does not induce high cytotoxicity or inflammation and has been proven to be biocompatible as well as osteoconductive material both in vitro and in vivo [236, 237]. Zirconia is considered as a bio-inert ceramic. Though few reports on the lack of cell or tissue interaction with zirconia [238], it was overcome by surface modification [239-243]. When implanted, it shows a morphological fixation with the surrounding tissues rather than any chemical or biological interaction. To further improve the effects of zirconia, bioactive materials such as BGC and HAp have been coated onto or incorporated into zirconia to have
29   
a synergistic effect of favorable mechanical properties of zirconia and bioactive properties of the coatings [244-253].
Nanomaterials explicit properties like high surface to volume ratio that widens the
area of application. The preparation of nZrO2 using sol-gel method is reported. Due to toxicity issues modifications in protocols were being introduced to develop biocompatible nZrO2 [254]. The zirconia phosphate nanoparticles of size 50nm were synthesized via a simple sonochemical method in the presence of cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide. Recently a simple and highly efficient method to synthesise of spherical mesoporous nZrO2 with a high surface area through a neutral surfactant-assisted sol-gel method was reported. The combination of alkali halides and vacuum extraction allowed stabilization of the shape and size of the nanoparticle and to avoid porous network failure, respectively [255]. The developed nanoparticles were biocompatible and showed cell uptake. Its use as pH sensitive drug release carrier showed effective release of curcumin [256]. Chitin isolated from marine sponge Aplysina cauliformis acted as template for the in vitro formation of nZrO2 from ammonium zirconium (IV) carbonate via hydrothermal treatment. The high temperature withstanding capability of chitin made it a suitable template for the development of this hybrid scaffold [257, 258]. nZrO2 found applications as reinforcing agent in various dental fillers. Hambire et al. incorporated zirconia nanoclusters within a polymer matrix to obtain dental filler. The study showed that addition of nZrO2 resulted in significant increase in mechanical stiffness and enhanced tissue adhesion due to the nanoagglomerate formation that formed good filler [259]. Lohbauer et al. developed nZrO2 system to be used as filler materials in dental adhesive [260]. nZrO2 (20-50 nm) were prepared via a laser vaporization method. These nanoparticles were incorporated within the adhesive layer and have shown to increase tensile strength and promote mineralization after implantation [261]. Various reports on preparation of nanocomposites with nZrO2 are presented. Preparation of chitosan/nZrO2 as
30   
coating material was done by electrophorectic deposition. Similarly, coating on stainless steel implant showed enhanced corrosive resistance and HAp deposition after immersion in SBF [262]. The incorporation of nZrO2 into the chitin/chitosan scaffold is thought to enhance osteogenesis [7]. The presence of nZrO2 in the chitosan/nSiO2/nZrO2 scaffold decreased swelling and increased biodegradation, protein adsorption and bio-mineralization properties [203]. Jayakumar et al. 2011, prepared the chitin-chitosan with nZrO2 nanocomposite scaffold by lyophilization technique [7]. The swelling, biomineralization, degradation, cell viability and cell adhesion of the nanocomposite scaffolds were evaluated. The nanocomposite scaffold showed an efficient mineralization in SBF and SEM and XRD studies confirmed a progressive increase in mineralization with time period. Preparative procedure of chitin/chitosan/nZrO2 composites and properties and application of n ZrO2 are shown in Fig. 8.
Fig. 8
Cell viability studies proved the non-toxic nature of the nanocomposite scaffolds
using MG-63 and L929 cells [7]. Tricomposite of chitosan, nSiO2 and nZrO2 was also found to be non-toxic to rat osteoprogenitor cells [203]. The preparative methods for the synthesis of nZrO2 determine the toxicity of the material [255], which could be drastically reduced by blending with natural polymers. The results suggested that the ZrO2 based composite scaffolds could be used for tissue engineering applications. A possible explanation for the bioactivity of zirconia would be that the presence of Zr in the composite scaffold decreases the swelling and increases biodegradation, protein adsorption and biomineralization properties. Results are promising for the use of chitin/chitosan/nZrO2 composite scaffold as potential candidate for bone tissue engineering. Thorough in vivo and ex vivo studies should be carried out to analyze the long term effect of the nZrO2 in composite scaffolds.
31

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions and Future perspectives
sections.text: In this review we overviewed the preparation, advantage, disadvantage and applications of chitin or chitosan/nHAp, chitin or chitosan/nBGC, chitin or chitosan/nSiO2, chitin or chitosan/nTiO2 and chitin or chitosan/nZrO2 in bone tissue engineering in detail. Although ample literatures has been reviewed in this single literary work, a lot of further studies such as toxicity, degradation and in vivo animal analyses of these scaffolds are required before using them for clinical trials/human use. Thus, this exclusive review that focuses on the various nanocomposite forms of chitin and chitosan with ceramics may prove to be very useful for the researchers working in the area of chitin and chitosan based composite scaffolds in bone tissue engineering. The use of nanoceramics in bone regeneration has the advantage of forming an osteintegrating surface with the native bone. Studies should be directed to compare the effects of such nanocomposites in in vivo scenario. Chitin/chitosan, being an extracellular mimicking biopolymer provides a suitable niche for the loading of cells. Tissue engineering constructs based on cell laden chitin/chitosan ceramics nanocomposite would be a better aspect to study on. The higher loading capacity of nanoceramics also opens up the prospect of using them as drug delivery vehicles. Incorporation of drugs that enhance bone formation, like strontium ranelate, or growth factors like BMP-2, FGF-18 etc is another possible application in addition to incorporating antibacterial drugs.
